awd_titl_txt: Virus-host interactions in the assembly of positive-strand RNA virus replication complexes
awd_abstract_narration:
Positive-strand RNA viruses are the largest among 7 viral classes, including many important human and animal pathogens as well as the great majority of plant viruses. Some examples include Zika virus, hepatitis C virus, foot and mouth disease virus, and cucumber mosaic virus. Despite infecting very different hosts and causing distinct symptoms, viruses in this class use similar strategies to replicate their genomic RNAs. As an indispensable process, viral replication also represents an excellent target for the development of antiviral strategies that should provide strong protection and apply to a wide range of important viral pathogens. This project aims to characterize the contributions of viral replication proteins and certain host proteins to viral replication and is expected to provide new insights on mechanisms required for viral replication as well as novel approaches for virus control. The project is also expected to provide undergraduate students from underrepresented groups with valuable experience in translational plant science and inspire them to seek more research opportunities and attend graduate schools in the field of plant science.    
	
A highly conserved feature of positive-strand RNA virus replication is that these viruses remodel host intracellular membranes to form their viral replication complexes (VRCs), an essential step in viral replication. Despite its critical importance, the mechanisms by which membranes are remodeled, the lipid microenvironment within VRCs, and the host proteins required for such processes are poorly understood. This project aims to address aforementioned knowledge gaps by using brome mosaic virus (BMV), a model virus used to study the common features shared by positive-strand RNA viruses. BMV invaginates the outer nuclear membrane to form spherular VRCs. The investigators had previously demonstrated that a group of viruses promote host phosphatidylcholine synthesis at the viral replication sites for supporting viral replication. In particular, BMV replication protein 1a interacts with and recruits an enzyme of phosphatidylcholine biosynthesis to the VRCs. The recruitment of the enzyme will be blocked by disrupting the specific protein-protein interactions to achieve virus resistance without affecting host lipid synthesis. Because the lipid composition of host intracellular membranes is dynamic and complicated, an in vitro assay has been developed to examine how BMV replication protein 1a and similar viral replication proteins generate membrane invaginations of liposomes with defined lipid compositions. In addition, host protein Erv14 has been found to be required for BMV replication. The mechanism whereby Erv14 is involved in BMV VRC assembly and the possible involvement of Erv14 in the replication of other plant viruses will be determined.

por.por_cntn:
Positive-strand RNA viruses [(+)RNA viruses] are the largest among seven viral classes and include numerous important pathogens infecting humans, animals, and plants, such as SARS-COV-2, Zika virus, and tobacco mosaic virus. All (+) RNA viruses remodel specific organelle membranes to form membrane-bound viral replication complexes (VRCs) to amplify their RNAs. The formation of VRCs include the targeting of viral replication proteins to the designated organelles, recruitment of host and viral proteins to the replication sites by the viral replication proteins, modify lipid compositions of membranes, and deform/remodel membranes to form single- or double-membrane vesicles. These VRCs protect viral RNAs serving as replication templates or intermediates, enrich critical viral and host proteins, separate viral replication from translation and encapsidation. A better understanding of VRC formation and maintenance will help reveal the mechanisms of viral replication and identify antiviral targets for viral control that are durable and broad spectrum. 

In this project, we used an engineered model system: brome mosaic virus (BMV)-yeast system and when possible, apply what we learned from BMV to other (+)RNA viruses. The specific objectives are as follows: 1. How BMV replication protein is targeted to the designated organelle membranes, the perinuclear endoplasmic reticulum; 2. How cellular membranes are remodeled by BMV 1a to form VRCs; 3. How BMV 1a promotes VRC-localized phospholipid synthesis and how we can control replication of BMV and other (+)RNA viruses by modulating host phospholipid synthesis.

For objective 1, we demonstrated that an 18-amino acid-long amphipathic alpha-helix is responsible for BMV 1a?s association with the nuclear membranes. Additionally, we showed this feature is conserved among multiple members from a conserved superfamily, the Alsuviricetes class, which include viruses infecting humans, animals, and plants. An equivalent helix from other members is responsible for targeting viral proteins to the endoplasmic reticulum, vacuoles, and the Golgi. For objective 2,  we have demonstrated the peptide representing the amphipathic alpha-helix in poliovirus 2C protein was able to remodel liposomes, suggesting the helix not only anchors a viral replication protein to the membranes but also play an active role in reshaping membranes. Please note that poliovirus 2C was included as a control and we are trying to solve the issues with peptides representing BMV 1a helices due to technical issues. For objective 3, we provided further evidence that phospholipid synthesis plays a key role in BMV replication. A significantly enhanced number of VRCs and enhanced BMV replication occurred when phospholipid synthesis was significantly promoted due to a block in the synthesis of storage lipids. We also demonstrated that substitutions in an enzyme involved in PC synthesis blocked BMV replication without compromising host growth, indicating it is possible to manipulate lipid synthesis for virus control without affecting host growth. These results have been published in PLoS Pathogens (2018), Journal of Biological Sciences (2019), Viruses (2020), and Frontiers in Microbiology (2020). A manuscript on the 18-amino acid-long amphipathic alpha-helix was just accepted in PLoS Pathogens.

This program primarily invested on undergraduate student education and training. We have provided multiple opportunities to include and nurture the interest of students from underrepresented groups: including them in research throughout the year, holding summer camps, and attending conferences. We have included underrepresented students from a Hispanic-serving university (La Sierra University) and a land grant university (Virginia Tech). We believe our effort will attract more student from underrepresented groups into the life sciences and agricultural science fields. During the period of the project, 11 UGs at Virginia Tech and 17 UGs at La Sierra University participated in the research; multiple students earned summer fellowship at VT; many have presented in professional conferences, such as the American Society for Virology (ASV), the Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students (ABRCMS), the Southern California Branch of the American Society for Microbiology (SCASM), and the West Coast Biological Sciences Undergraduate Research Conference (WCBSURC); students also attended summer research programs at Dartmouth, UCSD, Virginia Tech, the University of Wisconsin-Madison, and the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. Students went on to join PhD programs (3), medical school (9), law school (1), pharmacy school (1), or work as a research assistant in academic labs (2) and biotech companies (2). co-PI Dr. Diaz has created three lab courses based on his research project at La Sierra University, including two courses through the Howard Hughes Medical Institute sponsored Science Education Alliance, he was invited to an HHMI Science Education Department meeting to present his work on teaching, engagement, and mentorship during the pandemic, and he served on the HHMI?s Pedagogy of Research Team (PORT), leading to the publication of four pedagogical manuscripts that provide resources to help other educators engage their students in a manner that promotes their science identity.
